front.title: Using the SRP protocol as a key exchange method in Secure Shell

abstract.t: This memo describes an experimental method for authentication and keyexchange in the Secure Shell protocol. The main virtue of the SRP protocol [SRP] is that it provides authentication based on a small secret (typically a password). It is useful in situations where no authentic host key is known. For Secure Shell, it can be used as a bootstrapping procedure to get the host key of a server in a safe way. SRP also provides authentication of the user, which means that it might make sense to either skip the secsh 'ssh-userauth'-service [SSH-USERAUTH] when using SRP, or allow login with the 'none' or 'external-keyx' method.
